awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSE: Collaborative Research: Integrated Tools for DNA Nanostructure Design and Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology could one day revolutionize several activities of great importance to our national interest, including how we manufacture consumer products, how we diagnose and treat disease, and how we detect and neutralize threats to our defense. One promising approach to atomically precise construction is adapting molecular building blocks from living organisms such as DNA, RNA, and proteins, and repurposing them to self-assemble into prescribed shapes, devices, and materials. A key bottleneck to progress is the complexity of designing, building, and testing nanostructures comprised of thousands or millions of atoms. The goal of this project is to accelerate development of bio-inspired nanostructures by integrating two widely adopted software tools used in bio-nanostructure design and physics-based molecular simulation. The products of this effort will enhance our fundamental capability to understand and precisely engineer self-assembled biomolecular nanostructures, which, when coupled with experimental validation in the laboratory, will enable future demand-meeting applications of bionanotechnology.

Toward realizing the goal of programming matter with nanoscale precision, this project will develop software interfaces between two classes of molecular design programs that, until now, have been evolving independently from one another. A widely adopted DNA structure design program, Cadnano, will be extended to utilize the results of physics-based microscopic simulations, enabling an iterative structure design process. A leading molecular graphics program, VMD (Visual Molecular Dynamics), will be developed to seamlessly visualize Cadnano designs, provide their structural interpretation, and enable further modification of the structures using an arsenal of computational structural biology and nanotechnology tools. Both developments will utilize recent advances in cloud computing technologies, making the DNA structure design software available anywhere and to anyone in a platform-independent manner.

This project is supported by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering and the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation in the Directorate of Engineering.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The field of DNA nanotechnology is concerned with repurposing life's genetic information storage molecule to create custom nanoscale shapes, tools, and devices. A growing number of researchers design, create, and optimize DNA-based nanodevices to make methodological advances in several scientific disciplines, including  biological physics, materials research, sensing, computing, and medicine. Preliminary rules of self-assembly and shape design of DNA have been established by several groups, often relying on nature as a source of inspiration. However, in order to design and test increasingly complex and sophisticated nanodevices, new modeling methods and software tools are needed. To help realize the full potential of DNA nanotechnology, this project has developed a novel suite of software tools and educational materials that will advance and democratize multi-scale design, modeling, and simulation of DNA systems.  

Intellectual merit. Through integration of popular design and simulation  software tools, this project has enabled rapid yet accurate prototyping of self-assembled DNA nanosystems. The modeling framework developed considerably simplifies the setup of physics-based simulations of DNA nanostructures, dramatically lowering the barrier for performing such simulation by non-experts. The modeling and simulation software has been made available to the DNA nanotechnology community through public software repository and in the form of a webserver. As its ultimate outcome, this project will enable creation of new types of nanoscale self-assembled systems that can act as sensors, motors and drug delivery vehicles with applications ranging from engineering to medicine.

Broader impact. Complementing the software development efforts, the project produced educational material that provide step-by-step guide to setup and simulations of self-assembled DNA nanostructures. The project engaged the DNA nanotechnology community in the software development efforts by hosting a hands-on workshop that attracted participants from around the world and presenting the software and its capabilities at national and international meetings. The project's community building efforts will ensure that integration of design and simulation is rapidly adopted as a standard research practice. The design-simulation workflow developed through the project offers exciting opportunities for innovative applications in education and outreach.


Last Modified: 12/30/2020
Modified by: Aleksei Aksimentiev

    Multi-resolution simulation of self-assembled DNA nanostructures
